​Whether you’re a beginner, a seasoned plant collector, or somewhere in between, come connect with fellow plant lovers and grow your collection. Jasmine Neal, a self-taught plant researcher, will share a brief update on her work to launch a [plant-focused community biology lab](https://jasandolive.substack.com/p/plant-parenthood) in the East Bay. [Evan Groover](https://www.seedworld.com/us/2025/02/07/how-evan-groover-is-exploring-plant-synthetic-biology-and-democratizing-crispr/), a plant synthetic biologist, will lead a short group discussion on democratizing gene editing by making CRISPR accessible to independent researchers, farmers, breeders, and agronomists.

- ​6:00 pm-6:30 pm: Mingling

- ​6:30 pm-7:00 pm: Collective conversation about CRISPR and democratizing plant biology research

- ​7:00 pm-7:45 pm: Plant swap, raffles, and mingling


​Wine and non-alcoholic beverages will be provided, and you’ll have the chance to win houseplant accessories in our raffle.

​♻️ Plant swap guidelines

- ​We kindly ask that you bring cuttings or plants in 2” or 4” nursery pots.

- ​Ensure each plant is labeled. Scientific names are preferred but common names work too.

- ​If you’d like to buy a plant for the event, consider sourcing your plant from POC-owned East Bay plant shops such as [Blk Girls Green House](https://bggh.shop/), [Pamana Plantas](https://pamanaplantas.com/), and [Planterday](https://www.planterday.com/).

- ​After the event, be sure to quarantine your new plant for 1-2 weeks. Check for signs of pests or stress and treat accordingly before adding it to your plant collection.


​ **Spots are limited, so please update your RSVP if you’re unable to attend, allowing us to notify folks on the waitlist.** These houseplant swap events occur a few times a year at various locations throughout the East Bay. Subscribe to [Jas and Olive](https://jasandolive.substack.com/) if you’d like to stay in the loop for future swaps!

About Event

​Join us at Commure HQ for a fireside chat with **[Alfred Lin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/linalfred/)**, Partner at Sequoia and one of the minds behind Zappos’ legendary rise and sale to Amazon.

​From leading operations at Zappos to shaping Sequoia’s investment strategy through investments at AirBnB, DoorDash, OpenAI, & Citadel, Alfred brings a masterclass in scaling with culture. He'll sit down with **Tanay Tandon (CEO, Commure)** to unpack what it takes to be a leading engineer, product, or designer at a top tech company.

​Whether you're optimizing onboarding flows or rethinking system architecture, Alfred’s perspective will leave you with a sharper eye for building at scale—and insight into what Sequoia looks for in world-class teams.

​Dive deep into:

- ​How early product decisions shape enduring businesses

- ​What separates good product execution from great

- ​How design, engineering, and product come together to build experiences users love

- ​Lessons from working closely with founders and builders through zero-to-one and beyond

speaker_insight:
Alfred Lin is a Partner at Sequoia Capital, focusing on consumer, internet, and software investments. Before Sequoia, he was the COO, CFO, and Chairman of Zappos, playing a key role in its growth and eventual sale to Amazon. He has a background in computer science and previously worked at Venture Frogs and as an entrepreneur, co-founding LinkExchange, which was later acquired by Microsoft. Lin's experience spans operational leadership and venture capital, making him a valuable resource for startups. He currently serves on the boards of companies such as Airbnb and DoorDash.

*   [Alfred Lin's LinkedIn Profile](https://www.linkedin.com/in/alfredlin/)

*   **Podcast:** *Invest Like the Best, Alfred Lin - How to Go from Zero to a Billion*: (<https://www.joincolossus.com/episodes/22565-alfred-lin-how-to-go-from-zero-to-a-billion>). While this interview predates the 2-year window, it is highly relevant, providing valuable insights.

*   **Article**: *Sequoia’s Alfred Lin on How to Win at Investing (and Life)* (<https://www.sequoiacap.com/article/alfred-lin-how-to-win-at-investing-and-life/>) While not recent, but relevant because it is directly from Sequoia's website.

event_summary: Join us at Commure HQ for a fireside chat with Alfred Lin, Partner at Sequoia and one of the minds behind Zappos’ legendary rise and sale to Amazon. He'll sit down with Tanay Tandon (CEO, Commure) to unpack what it takes to be a leading engineer, product, or designer at a top tech company.

About Event

​Join us at Commure HQ for a fireside chat with **[Alfred Lin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/linalfred/)**, Partner at Sequoia and one of the minds behind Zappos’ legendary rise and sale to Amazon.

​From leading operations at Zappos to shaping Sequoia’s investment strategy through investments at AirBnB, DoorDash, OpenAI, & Citadel, Alfred brings a masterclass in scaling with culture. He'll sit down with **Tanay Tandon (CEO, Commure)** to unpack what it takes to be a leading engineer, product, or designer at a top tech company.

​Whether you're optimizing onboarding flows or rethinking system architecture, Alfred’s perspective will leave you with a sharper eye for building at scale—and insight into what Sequoia looks for in world-class teams.

​Dive deep into:

- ​How early product decisions shape enduring businesses

- ​What separates good product execution from great

- ​How design, engineering, and product come together to build experiences users love

- ​Lessons from working closely with founders and builders through zero-to-one and beyond


​We'll also have some refreshments and light bites!

​Open to the tech community — request to join before spots fill up!

- ​​ **Address:** 1300 Terra Bella Ave, Suite #200, Mountain View, CA 94043

- ​ **Parking:** Please feel free to park anywhere in the lot or on the street near the building.

- ​​Arrival: Please come through the front door and check in at the front desk using the Envoy kiosk.

About Event

​ **The climate crisis calls for community—and Climate Action Club is answering.**

​Join us for an urban hike along San Francisco’s [Crosstown Trail](https://crosstowntrail.org/) designed to spark deep connection, joyful movement, and a fresh perspective on what climate community can look like. We’ll start at Candlestick Point and wind our way through some of San Francisco’s most iconic parks and green corridors—stopping along the way for curated icebreakers, group reflections, and spontaneous moments to connect.

​Whether you’re joining for 6 miles (~12 PM) or going the full 18 (~6 PM), this is your invitation to move your body, meet values-aligned peers, and build relationships that last longer than your average meetup.

​

We believe the strongest climate communities are built through shared experiences—both virtually and IRL. Walking side-by-side creates space for real conversation, and that’s where change begins.

​ **Hike Overview**

- ​ **Start:** Candlestick Point

- ​ **Major Stops:** Mission Blue Coffee, McLaren Park Overlook, St. Mary’s Park, Glen Canyon, Grandview Park, Strawberry Hill, Baker Beach

- ​ **End:** Lands End (18 miles total)


​Each stop includes time to rest, chat, and engage in lightly facilitated group activities. Want to hike just a portion? Totally fine. We’ll send a pre-hike survey so you can indicate where you plan to stop—whether that’s 3 miles in or all the way at the edge of the continent.

​ **Event Flow**

- ​Meetup + first circle: Candlestick Point

- ​Sectioned hike with 2–3 intentional group breaks per phase

- ​Optional ending points at 6, 9, 11, or 18 miles

- ​Final photo and closing vibes at Lands End


​ **What to Bring**

- ​Comfortable walking shoes or trail runners

- ​Water (bring more than you think)

- ​Snacks or light lunch

- ​Layers (SF microclimates are real)

- ​Sunscreen, sun hat, or both

- ​MUNI/BART card in case you head out early


​ **​Community Principles**

- ​​​​​Growth Mindset: We are committed to learning together, deepening our understanding of climate challenges, and taking action where we’re best positioned.

- ​​​​​Relationships, Not Transactions: We prioritize genuine connections over networking for opportunities, recognizing that strong relationships drive lasting change.

- ​​​​​Inclusivity & Diversity: A range of perspectives, backgrounds, and experiences enriches our community and leads to better engagement and solutions.

- ​​​​​Mutual Respect: We foster a respectful space where all voices are heard. We may not always agree, but we’re here to learn and grow together.


​ **​​​​Guidelines**

- ​​​​​​​Be Kind: Listen actively when others are speaking. Avoid interrupting or dominating conversations.

- ​​​​​​​Be Friendly and Approachable: Smile and introduce yourself to new people, especially those who may have shown up alone! Be open to meeting new people and making connections.

- ​​​​​​​Be Mindful of Time: Keep conversations balanced, allowing others to speak and share. Respect the event’s schedule and timing.

- ​​​​​​​Enjoy Yourself: Have fun making friends and meeting peers who share your passion for climate! Remember, everyone is there to make connections just like you.

Request to Join

You will be asked to verify token ownership with your wallet.

About Event

​ **The climate crisis calls for community—and Climate Action Club is answering.**

​Join us for an urban hike along San Francisco’s [Crosstown Trail](https://crosstowntrail.org/) designed to spark deep connection, joyful movement, and a fresh perspective on what climate community can look like. We’ll start at Candlestick Point and wind our way through some of San Francisco’s most iconic parks and green corridors—stopping along the way for curated icebreakers, group reflections, and spontaneous moments to connect.

​Whether you’re joining for 6 miles (~12 PM) or going the full 18 (~6 PM), this is your invitation to move your body, meet values-aligned peers, and build relationships that last longer than your average meetup.

​

We believe the strongest climate communities are built through shared experiences—both virtually and IRL. Walking side-by-side creates space for real conversation, and that’s where change begins.

​ **Hike Overview**

- ​ **Start:** Candlestick Point

- ​ **Major Stops:** Mission Blue Coffee, McLaren Park Overlook, St. Mary’s Park, Glen Canyon, Grandview Park, Strawberry Hill, Baker Beach

- ​ **End:** Lands End (18 miles total)


​Each stop includes time to rest, chat, and engage in lightly facilitated group activities. Want to hike just a portion? Totally fine. We’ll send a pre-hike survey so you can indicate where you plan to stop—whether that’s 3 miles in or all the way at the edge of the continent.

​ **Event Flow**

- ​Meetup + first circle: Candlestick Point

- ​Sectioned hike with 2–3 intentional group breaks per phase

- ​Optional ending points at 6, 9, 11, or 18 miles

- ​Final photo and closing vibes at Lands End


​ **What to Bring**

- ​Comfortable walking shoes or trail runners

- ​Water (bring more than you think)

- ​Snacks or light lunch

- ​Layers (SF microclimates are real)

- ​Sunscreen, sun hat, or both

- ​MUNI/BART card in case you head out early


​ **​Community Principles**

- ​​​​​Growth Mindset: We are committed to learning together, deepening our understanding of climate challenges, and taking action where we’re best positioned.

- ​​​​​Relationships, Not Transactions: We prioritize genuine connections over networking for opportunities, recognizing that strong relationships drive lasting change.

- ​​​​​Inclusivity & Diversity: A range of perspectives, backgrounds, and experiences enriches our community and leads to better engagement and solutions.

- ​​​​​Mutual Respect: We foster a respectful space where all voices are heard. We may not always agree, but we’re here to learn and grow together.


​ **​​​​Guidelines**

- ​​​​​​​Be Kind: Listen actively when others are speaking. Avoid interrupting or dominating conversations.

- ​​​​​​​Be Friendly and Approachable: Smile and introduce yourself to new people, especially those who may have shown up alone! Be open to meeting new people and making connections.

- ​​​​​​​Be Mindful of Time: Keep conversations balanced, allowing others to speak and share. Respect the event’s schedule and timing.

- ​​​​​​​Enjoy Yourself: Have fun making friends and meeting peers who share your passion for climate! Remember, everyone is there to make connections just like you.
